title: Silence, Statuses, and the Strange Weight of Digital Presence
excerpt: After 16 days without daily standups or real engagement, Iâ€™m reflecting on fake connections, digital noise, and what value actually looks like.
content:
# Silence, Statuses, and the Strange Weight of Digital Presence

Itâ€™s the 16th today â€” and itâ€™s been **16 days without a stand-up**, without teammates, and with very little real engagement. I recently wrapped up my previous role and have done a couple of interviews since, but for the most part, Iâ€™m in that strange in-between: not quite transitioning yet, but also no longer in motion. Itâ€™s quiet.  
The photo above? I took it earlier this year, just after driving through the Magoebaskloof mountain pass. One of those still moments that matched the mood of this post perfectly.

## Early Lessons in People

I learned a lot about people long before adulthood â€” probably earlier than I should have. My family went through real ups and downs, and those seasons taught me how to read individuals without needing anyone to explain the game to me.

Some might mistake that for being judgmental. But here's the thing: **weâ€™re all allowed to form perceptions based on what we observe**. What matters is what we do with those perceptions *after* we get to know someone. If you refuse to update your view of someone even after learning who they truly are, thatâ€™s not gut instinct anymore â€” thatâ€™s just rigid judgment. Thereâ€™s a line, and most people blur it.

From my experience, I saw it firsthand. People who were always around â€” braais, gatherings, good times â€” but when things got rough? Gone. Not only that, some of them even had the audacity to ask for help later, as if they hadnâ€™t disappeared when we needed them.

That contrast stuck with me. I started seeing the same pattern in friendships too. Youâ€™d have all-rounder friends â€” the ones who show up for everything â€” and then a thousand â€œpurpose-specificâ€ people: the fun friends, the work besties, the convenience connections.

And some people? They only come closer when thereâ€™s something you can offer them â€” whether thatâ€™s knowledge, connections, clout, or comfort. Like moths to a flame, but only while itâ€™s burning. The moment the light dims, they disappear, off to the next glow.

And this wasnâ€™t a lesson I learned in my twenties. I understood this stuff clearly by the time I was ten. That awareness hasnâ€™t made me cynical, but it has made me deliberate. I donâ€™t mistake presence for loyalty. I donâ€™t confuse visibility for value.

## Connections That Donâ€™t Connect

Iâ€™m fortunate to be connected with a few respected professionals â€” businessmen, scholars, even former ministers. But when it really comes down to it, Iâ€™ve been asking myself: **how many of them could I actually reach out to in a moment of need?**

And beyond that â€” **whatâ€™s the cost of maintaining real, valuable relationships with people at that level?** Thereâ€™s a delicate balance between misusing someoneâ€™s name to gain an unfair advantage, and genuinely reaching out to say, *â€œCan you vouch for me to at least get through the door?â€* â€” knowing full well that what happens next is still on me.

Itâ€™s one of those grey areas people donâ€™t really talk about. You can know the right people. You can even be in the same room. But if the relationship isnâ€™t nurtured or built on mutual value, youâ€™re just a name in a long contact list. And thatâ€™s not connection. Thatâ€™s decoration.

Thatâ€™s one of the reasons I stopped interacting on LinkedIn altogether. My profile lives in hibernation mode â€” I only activate it when Iâ€™m job hunting. Iâ€™m not trying to grow an audience or build some mythical â€œpersonal brand.â€ My digital presence is just another resume, and honestly, it doesnâ€™t even scratch 1% of who I am or what Iâ€™m capable of.

## Recognition Isnâ€™t the Goal

Iâ€™ve noticed how some people post almost every day â€” and yet, they still face the same challenges as those whose content gets little to no interaction. Thatâ€™s when it hit me: **interaction without action is just distraction**. It creates the illusion of movement, but not real progress. And most of the people engaging? Theyâ€™re not invested â€” just scrolling.

Thereâ€™s something strange about the digital world rewarding *activity* over *impact*. Recently, I saw five different accounts being praised for sharing outdated and incorrect info â€” claiming AWS was offering free certification exams, months after that promo had ended. Only a handful, against tens of thousands, called out the misinformation. Not one person in the comments questioned it. It was just likes, fire emojis, and â€œthanks for sharing.â€

That moment stuck with me. Weâ€™ve reached a point where **most people donâ€™t pause long enough to process one thing before being flooded by five more**. Facts barely matter anymore. Metrics do. Attention becomes currency, even if it's built on fluff or falsehoods.

Iâ€™m not wired for that kind of game. I donâ€™t need recognition to validate my work. Would it be nice? Sure. But what really satisfies me is seeing something Iâ€™ve contributed to *actually working* out in the world â€” quietly doing its job.

Thatâ€™s real. Thatâ€™s enough for me.

## No Socials, More Sanity

Thereâ€™s something freeing about not constantly being pulled into timelines, trends, and opinions that donâ€™t align with where I am mentally or emotionally.

If I could shape an ideal space, it would have dedicated audiences based on their interests â€” really taken into consideration â€” unlike how we select preferences on platforms like X or Instagram but still get flooded with noise.

It would also limit how much content someone consumes over a given period, factoring in not just quantity but substance. With sentiment analysis, it could help flag when content is becoming emotionally overwhelming â€” not to censor, but to protect. Add to that a layer of personality awareness â€” tuning the experience to how different people process emotion, motivation, and connection â€” and suddenly you're not just consuming contentâ€¦ you're in a space *designed with you in mind*.

To be honest, this might be something I take seriously â€” a real product, not just a thought experiment. Maybe itâ€™s my way back into the founder zone.

When it comes to people, Iâ€™ve come to value **depth over reach**. Iâ€™d rather have five solid, reliable connections I can truly build with than be surrounded by a crowd thatâ€™s only loosely present. These days, **alignment matters more than attention** â€” and peace matters more than performance.

## Just Thinking Out Loud

This post isnâ€™t a rant. Itâ€™s just me thinking out loud while I navigate this quiet middle space. Waiting. Reflecting. Rebuilding.

Somewhere in the silence, thereâ€™s something solid forming. Iâ€™ll know it when I see it.

â€” One for the geeks coming next.

title: Redis, NATS JetStream KV, and the Art of Distributed Caching
excerpt: Redis is blazing fast, NATS JetStream KV adds event-backed versioning â€” both shine in different ways when it comes to distributed caching. Hereâ€™s how Iâ€™ve been thinking about them lately.
content:
# In-Memory Caching in Distributed Systems: Redis, NATS JetStream KV, and Beyond

The past few weeks have been a bit of a whirlwind. I wrapped up last-round interviews, got a few offers, and eventually accepted one. I'll be starting in September. I'm both excited and nervous, especially after two months with no "structure." But I won't dwell too much on that right now â€” because I'd promised to share something technical.

## Redis: The Classic Workhorse

Redis is often the go-to when people think about caching. It's lightning fast, largely because it's single-threaded â€” meaning no race conditions from multiple threads competing. Combined with efficient memory structures, this design makes Redis incredibly reliable for high-throughput caching.

### Eviction Policies
- **LRU (Least Recently Used):** Evicts the least recently accessed keys.
- **LFU (Least Frequently Used):** Evicts keys with the fewest hits.
- **TTL-based:** Keys expire after a set time.

Choosing the right policy depends on your system's usage patterns. For example, if you're caching frequently accessed configs, LFU works better. For session storage, TTL might be the safer bet.

```go
// Redis Example: Basic caching with TTL
package main

import (
    "context"
    "fmt"
    "github.com/redis/go-redis/v9"
    "time"
)

func main() {
    ctx := context.Background()
    rdb := redis.NewClient(&redis.Options{
        Addr: "localhost:6379",
    })

    // Set with TTL
    err := rdb.Set(ctx, "user:123", "Mandlenkosi", 10*time.Second).Err()
    if err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }

    val, err := rdb.Get(ctx, "user:123").Result()
    if err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }
    fmt.Println("Cached value:", val)
}
```

## NATS JetStream KV: The Event-Backed Alternative

Redis may dominate, but NATS JetStream KV offers something Redis doesn't: versioned key-value storage backed by events. This means every change to a key is stored as a stream event. You don't just know the current value; you can inspect its history, replay changes, and even build reactive systems.

```go
// NATS JetStream KV Example: Versioned key-value store
package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "log"
    "github.com/nats-io/nats.go"
)

func main() {
    nc, _ := nats.Connect(nats.DefaultURL)
    js, _ := nc.JetStream()

    // Create or access a KV bucket
    kv, err := js.CreateKeyValue(&nats.KeyValueConfig{
        Bucket: "configs",
    })
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }

    // Put a value
    rev, _ := kv.Put("feature_flag", []byte("enabled"))
    fmt.Println("Revision:", rev)

    // Get the value
    entry, _ := kv.Get("feature_flag")
    fmt.Printf("Key: %s, Value: %s, Revision: %d\n",
        entry.Key(), string(entry.Value()), entry.Revision())
}
```

## Key Differences

### Redis

**ğŸ† Strengths**  
â€¢ Blazing fast performance  
â€¢ Simple key-value operations  
â€¢ Rich data structures (strings, hashes, lists, etc.)

**ğŸ¯ Best For**  
â€¢ Simple caching  
â€¢ Session storage  
â€¢ Rate limiting  
â€¢ Real-time analytics

**âš¡ Performance**  
â€¢ Sub-millisecond response times  
â€¢ Single-threaded, no lock contention  
â€¢ Optimized for read-heavy workloads

**ğŸ’¾ Persistence**  
â€¢ Optional persistence  
â€¢ Configurable durability (RDB snapshots, AOF logs)  
â€¢ Can run entirely in-memory

---

### NATS JetStream KV

**ğŸ† Strengths**  
â€¢ Event-sourced architecture  
â€¢ Versioned data with history  
â€¢ Built-in message replay  
â€¢ Native distributed systems support

**ğŸ¯ Best For**  
â€¢ Configuration management  
â€¢ Feature flags  
â€¢ Audit trails  
â€¢ Event-driven architectures

**âš¡ Performance**  
â€¢ Fast, but slightly slower due to event logging  
â€¢ Optimized for write-heavy workloads  
â€¢ Horizontal scaling capabilities

**ğŸ’¾ Persistence**  
â€¢ Built-in persistence  
â€¢ Configurable retention policies  
â€¢ Replication across clusters

## Side Note

On a lighter note, while learning caching I was also getting serious about eFootball. I moved from Division 10 to Division 3, then "graduated" back to FIFA since the gameplay feels slightly different. Just like caching systems, I guess games also reward consistent practice and adapting to the rules of the environment.

â€” One for the geeks, delivered.
